physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top.

encodingDesc.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: We will, as I said before, make a little bow to you in the preface of the next Anthology. But do not go on blaming Houghton Mifflin for what was none of their business. Publishers can not control authors’ prefaces; all publishers can do is to take or leave a book. So you must throw whatever blame you have on us, and remember that in mentioning “Poetry” in the preface of the new volume, we shall do so spontaneously and con amore and not in the least because you ask it, for I think your deserts great and your contention wrong.

As to your review of us and bringing in Ezra, you say in this letter that you still consider him a member of the Imagist group and, therefore, that it was natural you should mention him; but you seem to forget that our title was “Some Imagist Poets,” meaning that we only represented a portion of the group. We never laid claim to being the whole group, but I do wish that in the eyes of so many of you Ezra’s shadow did not lie with
such sharp edges over us all. Greatly as I admire Ezra’s work, I think other members of the group are as deserving as he and as important. The slenderness of Ezra’s output alone, and it is getting slenderer and slenderer of late years, is sure to affect his central position. I know his theory about overproduction very well, and of course, in the main, he is right; but so very slight a production as his cannot fail to be remarked upon as showing a lack of vigour, or inspiration, or large fecundity. Praise him as much as you like in reviewing his own things, but do, for Heaven’s sake, let our things stand on their own merits without reference to Ezra.

You never mentioned to me in your letter what was to me the most important thing in my letter: namely, whether it is in August or September that you are going to give me my group, and open the ball with them. I think it is probably September, and September will suit me perfectly well. May I count on that?
I hope you have not been drowned out as we have. I have never seen such rain as we have been having here.
